  4063. It does get though my baby fine hair without a problem, but the bristles appear thin and I will have to see how well
  4064. I have medium length, fine, thin hair
  4065. Works well with my daughter's thick hair- wet or dry :)
  4066. and the wet brush definitely seems to tangle less, which I think is due to thinner bristles not having enough resistance to get caught in knots easily.
  4067. This brush has definitely been gentler on my hair; I don't know if it pulls less hair out, but I definitely like that the actual brush pin things are gentle on my scalp and any knots.
  4068. I bought this for my Granddaughter who has major problems with detangeling her long hair
  4069. I'm a cute chubby little 4 year old getting my morning hair style for another tough day of kindergarten.
  4070. The bristles don't look different, so I'm not sure what the difference is other than the handles (which I wouldn't think would account for the performance), but this second brush does not move smoothly through the hair at all.
  4071. the wet brush brushes them right out, painlessly, wet or dry.
  4072. It is the only brush my little one wants me to use in her hair
  4073. If you have thick, wavy, curly, or even fine hair that you struggle brushing when its wet this hairbrush is definitely for you!
  4074. it's so hard to know what's worth it
  4075. I have very long, thick hair, so I was excited to try this &#34;amazing brush&#34;.
  4076. />The first time we used it, it got almost 100% of the knots out with very little pulling.
  4077. I too spent 20 minutes or more every morning brushing out my very thick, curly red hair, but now I don't have to!
  4078. With high hopes I got this, but I am completly let down.
  4079. would highly recommend The Wet Brush to anyone who is looking to end the tearful drama at hair-brushing time!!
  4080. VERY little hair came out, and they were just strands -- not clumps of snarled hair (which is what normally happened with my regular old comb.)
  4081. This brush goes right through those messy tangles...wet or dry!
  4082. I even like to use it because I feel like it is more gentle on my hair and doesn't break it off as bad.
  4083. It's still painful, sure, but the difference is really uncanny.
  4084. This brush works really well, but I'm afraid I got a cheap knockoff.

All Reviews

  1. I thought a brush was just a brush but this one works better than any brush I've bought from the drugstore. It glides through my hair and detangles. It doesn't rip out my hair like other brushes do. I have long black, thin straight, Asian hair.
  2. This is the best brush ever!<br /><br />Our toddler would flat out refuse to let us brush her long curly hair.<br /><br />Since we have gotten this, she doesn't even realize when we are brushing her hair. Even if it's tangled.<br /><br />Thank you wet brush!!
  3. Great brush. My daughter calls it her magic brush. It is pink though so you might want to be careful ordering it on Amazon without a color selection possibility.
  4. I wish my hairdresser would buy this because every time I get my hair cut or colored there it is torture! This worked even better than I expected. I have frizzy, easily tangled hair, and before I bought this brush I was using a detangling comb on my hair after washing it. The comb would pull my hair and there was always lots of hair in the comb. This brush glides through easily without pulling and so far I haven't seen hair in the brush, which means it isn't breaking my hair like the comb did. Update 4/11/15: This also works well for me on dry hair, especially if my hair is frizzy or tangled. I have had this brush for 6 months now and I still love it and use it every day.
  5. this works great as long as your hair is really wet. I ended up getting 2 because my husband took my first one for himself.
  6. This brush smells like petroleum/plastic. It smells stronger than others that I have purchased. My first wet brush (I still use it!) has a harder finish. The newer versions smell, including &#34;knock offs&#34; or other brands. I don't think it is a problem specific to this vendor. I looked on Wet Brush's FaceBook page, and they did have some people complaining about the smell. Their response (paraphrasing here) was that because the rubber is so new, it can be difficult to know which ones may still have a stronger smell. They suggested putting it outside in the sun for several hours to alleviate the smell. I have tried this, but its turned cold here, and I have trees overhead in my back yard. Next up I may try putting it under a heat lamp for a bit, etc.<br /><br />I gave three stars because I do not think the odor is a problem from this vendor, but rather the Wet Brush itself, as there have been repeated problems, even when buying directly from department stores, etc. I will continue to try new things (short of baking the brush!) to get rid of the smell. Until then, I can't use it.
  7. Works great in my daughter's hair. It used to take a really long time to pick through her hair with a comb and would cause her a lot of pain, this brush goes right through her hair in a minute or two. Her hair is very straight and she doesn't have a lot of it, but it is fine and gets very tangled and almost matted in the back as she sleeps. But it's less tangly now after we've used this brush for a few months, I think because there is less breakage.
  8. This brushed has saved us a lot of screaming after showers. Thank you.
  9. My daughter loves this brush because it does not pull her hair! I also love the drama free brushing !
  10. Absolutely amazing. I would have a screaming match with my daughter every day over brushing her curly hair. We would use a lot of detangler and she still had huge knots that took forever to get thru and it was torture. The wet brush is UNBELIEVABLE!! It took 5 minutes to go thru her hair which is pretty curly and is halfway down her back. There was no screaming, no crying and even she said &#34;this brush is amazing&#34;!! Best purchase ever!
  11. Love love love this brush. Gets through all the tangles without pulling and hurting at all.
  12. detangles hair with little pain, but alot of hair comes off onto the brush
  13. This is my 2nd wet brush. I want to give it 5 stars, but after a while the bristles start bending, almost in an L shape. Not all of them, but some of them get misshapen. The brush is cheap so I just replaced. I love this brush overall and doesn't hurt when I am detangling my wet, tangly hair or brushing over extensions. Also great for brushing out extensions, most other brushes pull the hairs out of the threading.
  14. this brush really does work when my hair is wet in the shower or damp after towel drying. not so much with dry hair but it is soft yet sturdy enough to brush the hair without pulling too much. i like it a lot and would recommend, especially to moms or dads that have to remove their kid's (bird nest) knots, haha. i remember those days with my daughter, not fun, lol. the company picks a color for you and sends it. i got the pink one, very cute. may not be worth the $9 and change, a little overpriced, but it works and i probably would buy again.
  15. This is the second brush I have purchased! My daughter s can't live with out it! We really Love this product!
  16. This brush is amazing. I have ordered 5 now (for myself and as gifts) and I plan to order more. My 2 year old god daughter has a sensitive head, but she likes this brush! I also got one for my best friend and her 8 year old loves it as well. This brush works wonders for adults and children. I get horrible migraines, and the last thing I want to do is brush my hair when my head is throbbing. This brush is so gentle that I don't have any problems using it with a migraine!
  17. I wish I had known about this magical product sooner. This thing has saved time and energy I would have otherwise spent arguing with my child about brushing her hair. It works amazingly well on both wet and dry hair. No more arguing and no more tears. Woo hoo! Thank you Wet Brush!
  18. This hairbrush came highly recommended to me by several friends. I used to use a comb for wet hair and brush for dry hair but now I only need to pack this wet brush and it does it all.   24. I bought two brushes for my 10 year old daughter. This brush and the detangled brush. She is very head sensitive and I was tired of all the pouting when I was brushing her hair. This brush worked the best. If you have thick hair you will have to do it in sections to get underneath.
  25. I have been using a Tangle Teezer on my daughters fairly thick 3c curls for years. They have served us well, so I was a little hesitant to try anything else, but with the good reviews, I thought I would give wet brush a try. I LOVE it! It works just as well as the tangle Teezer for detangling. I can't share brushes with my daughter because of the creams and oils I use in her hair, so I plan to get my own wet brush because i like it so much. The only negative I will mention is not something specific to wet brush, but sometimes when detangling, a few hairs will snag and catch a little clump of bristles because of the little beads on the end of the bristles. The tangle Teezer doesn't have this specific issue because it doesn't have the beads on its bristles, but regardless I really like the wet brush. Thanks!!

I think I recalled someone saying that the bristles melted and I'm not sure what dryer they were using but I have a Babyliss Pro BAB2000 and they don't melt. The brush hasn't popped out of its confines which with my thick hair is a common occurrence. I can't really comment on breakage because my hair does that all the time because I don't really get split ends when it breaks (to the ire of my friends) but the brush glides through easily without struggle through wet tangled hair.

  40. I very rarely write reviews about products, but this brush merited a glowing one. For forty years I have bought the sturdiest, most stable bristled brushes I can find. My hair is extremely thick, naturally curly/wavy and to-the-butt long. My hair has been known to break wooden brushes, plastic brushes, combs, picks and once on an extreme mass even an ice pick! I have had to cut bunches of snarls out and I've sat with my hair slathered in mayo under a styling cap. I read every review available for these brushes and I still had major reservations. When the brush arrived, I had my doubts as it just didn't look sturdy enough to deal with my hair. To my surprise, in 15 minutes I had easily dry brushed through all my hair, including two clumpy thickets of snarls that would have taken me a half hour to forty five minutes to work through. I thought at first it couldn't be going all the way through my very thick hair because it was brushing so easily, but it was. There was very little pulling and not much hair loss at all. It worked beautifully on damp, after the shower hair with very little effort. I most certainly will be ordering more of these brushes and recommending them to my thick haired friends!

This, I think, gives it the ability to go through my hair without breaking it but somehow (magically) completely detangles it.<br /><br />The first time brushed it I think I expected it to slide through my hair and not to feel any of the tangles.   73. The bristles on this brush are skinny, which means for very thick or very long hair (when dry) they don't stay straight enough to get tangles out. It does work nicely on wet hair, but we have found that brushing long hair while it's wet tends to leave it straight as a stick, and the description mentions \\"works great on wet and dry hair\\". If you don't mind brushing while wet, it's great, but minus two stars for minimal effectiveness on dry hair.

It went right through the tangles, and I have a very sensitive scalp. within minutes, my hair was completely brushed through perfectly.<br /><br />I paid $6.98 for this brush, and honestly would pay $30 or more for it, just because it has been such a lifesaver for my daughter. Now, she doesn't fight me when it's time to brush, and it saves so much time. Not to mention, this hair brush is going to pay for itself in the amount of money I save not having to buy detangling sprays (which don't work nearly as well, btw).<br /><br />As for the quality of the brush, I know some people have complained about it. I think the bristles are 'cheap' feeling because of how they have to be made to get this brush to work the way it does. I don't think it was made intentionally cheap, but I have never seen a hairbrush with bristles like these, and I think that's how it gets the tangles out. The quality of the brush is actually nice. The brush has a nice rubberized feel to it and thebrush feels weighty, not just a light cheap throwaway. I can see this brush lasting for quite some time.<br /><br />For reference, my daughter has shoulder length baby fine, hair with light curls. My hair is very fine, straight, and thick. From the tangled thick mess my hair was in for my experiment, I would definitely say that anybody with ultra thick curly hair would be able to use this also.<br /><br />Also, one more tip: I have noticed, that this brush does work remarkably better on damp or wet hair. We have used it on dry hair, but it does pull on tangles somewhat when it is dry. If you want to use this without having had a shower, just keep a small spray bottle and lightly mist your hair before brushing. It doesn't have to be soaked, it works really good with just a light spritzing. I have to clarify though, this is for hair that is extremely tangled. It does fine on dry hair that is not tangled much.

I am amazed that the brush does go through my hair but the soft bristles are firm enough to tug, but soft enough to not break the hair. I find that it probably takes extra strokes To get the tangles out, but this brush is gentler on my hair and I'm having less breakage. My hair can have a tendency to get somewhat poofy especially in damp or humid weather, so I use conditioner and leave in Argan oil.   229. Never thought I'd actually love a hair brush so much as this one. I am growing out my hair to donate, and it is about half way down my back at this point. I had gotten used to the tangling knots and tearing my hair out every time I brushed it... My old brush started loosing bristles so I thought Id give this one a try - not expecting it to be too much different, but WOW!! Yes, there is a (slightly) strong smell at first - smells like the rubber soles of new shoes or new tires. This is because there is rubber in the brush - so, naturally, it will smell like rubber. But the smell is not overpowering and fades after a few days out of the package, so its not nearly as big of a deal as other reviewers have made it.<br />It glides through my thick long hair with ease, and keeps it shiny and smooth. As apposed to my other brush which was MUCH more expensive, but would painfully tear at my hair creating more knots than it let out! I think the secret is that the bristles are thinner and therefore move easier than most brushes of a similar type. We will see how this stands the test of time, as I only just got it. But assuming it doesn't fall apart - I will likely never buy another brush!

  293. I was initially skeptical about this brush working wonders because my hair is a nightmare! I have really long, medium-fine hair, but my hair is thick. The texture is wavy and it tangles within 5 minutes of brushing it. I HATE washing it for the sole reason of having to try to brush it out. I decided to try this brush after my hairdresser used it on me. I LOVE IT. I use it in conjunction with my normal paddle brush. I use the wet brush first to get out crazy tangles and to brush it completely, then I use my paddle brush to get the remaining knots out and underlying knots out. Using the wet brush with my paddle brush has cut my hair brushing time in half. I would totally recommend it.
  294. I have very long and rather thick hair but it's oily so over conditioning to deal with tangles just makes my hair look dirty. I've had the same issues with detangling spray and pretty much everything else I've tried. I also don't like a lot of product in my hair so this brush has been ideal. I use it in the shower to comb through conditioner and I use it after my shower to brush out the tangles. Works great and I would recommend it to anyone who has issues with tangled hair.
  295. Seriously?!?! This is like night and day. No kidding, I can't believe I could actually brush my daughter's hair, wet, dry, I could blow it dry and style it...and we're still on speaking terms. My girl has a lot of hair, but it's very fine...and it tangles just by looking at it hard, and tears and screams and hatred were always the result of any attempt to brush. So I kind of gave up. My daughter typically went to school a little tousled looking. My hair stylist casually mentioned the Wet Brush, I read some reviews... decided I could afford to take a chance for $7. The BEST $7 I've ever spent in my life. I'm thinking about buying stock in this company. It's a miracle for our family. If you have hair brushing problems with your child and you decide not to buy this brush, you're just asking for pain and heartache.

After seeing a few other reviewers mention this I am going to stop using it for a couple months and maybe I will update then if I've seen an improvement.

  310. I have long hair, right about to my waist. It's fine (although I braid it often, so it feels coarser and thicker once I unbraid it), but once it gets this long, it tangles easily and often, even though I use more conditioner and try different ones as well, inclduing ones claiming to detangle. I can't comb through my hair, no comb can handle it, so I need a brush. Wet or dry, detangling it is always painful, I have to go through small sections at a time and hold my hair away from my scalp to avoid pulling and pain. I bought this brush and also Tangle Teezer, hoping one or the other would help. I am seriously shocked at how well this brush works. I can run this through my hair, wet or dry, and about 90% of the time there's no snagging or pulling at all, just glides right through and detangles perfectly. Occasionally I do have to work a section more carefully, but it takes much less time than before, and more importantly, it's not painful the way it was before. Tangle Teezer is also good, but I prefer the Wet Brush because it has the traditional handle, which I like and is more comfortable for me to use. As a bonus, they sent me the brush in purple, my favorite color, but for this kind of effectiveness, I would gladly have taken any color they make. Seriously, Wet Brush makers, whoever you are, THANK YOU!!! In the past, I've always cut my hair when it got this long, because I couldn't deal with the tangles anymore. Now I can leave it long if I like, and brushing my hair is no longer a (literal) pain. BEST BRUSH EVER!!!

  312. I have two daughters who have very long slightly wavy hair. I needed something that would work out their tangles. You know the kind of tangles they get from bed-head, using pony-tails, wearing hats, and flipping their hair in and out of their jackets. It worked wonders on my youngest daughter's hair and she is so so pleased with it that she takes it into the shower with her and brushes by herself. We've had lots of brushes and, for her, this is the best brush. It doesn't work as well with my older daughter's hair, which is slightly finer and silkier than my youngest daughter's. I find the brush bristles bend too easily to get any of her tough hair tangles out. Granted, it didn't pull her hair or hurt her either, but it took a longer time to work the snarls out. It works great on my own medium length curly/wavy hair. I think it all depends on your hair type if this works for you or not.

  360. I stumbled across this product in search of something that will de-tangle my natural thick, curly and coarse hair. When I received this product; it had a strand of blonde hair in it and the packaging was stapled down as if the product was used prior. I ordered it as a new product but that's neither here or there. The &#34;WET&#34; brush does what it is suppose to do and then some. This brush went through my hair like butter; no stops, very very few snags and frizz free de-tangling when used on my hair (wet and dry). I discovered that the snags were cause by the manufacturing of the bristles within the brush. It looked like the bristles were bent and stuffed into the padding of the brush; like bending a drinking straw to fit into a small test tube. Since using it; some of the bristles on the brush became pushed down into the padding of brush. When used on my mothers hair which is very thin, curly and coarse due to health reasons. When I used this on my mothers hair (wet and dry); the product de-tangled very well but left a bit of frizz and some snagging of the hair along the way. The only downfall is that the WET brush doesn't smooth the hair; it might create little to no frizz but that differs from the type and grade of hair YOU have. This brush is truly meant for de-tangling and NOT for styling purposes; i'd recommend a Denman 8 row brush for styling. Overall I give this product a 4/5 star rating for that the product needs a better, more sturdy manufacturing; other than that i'd recommend it to all members of a family; it does what it's suppose to do.

  377. This is THE BEST detangling hairbrush ever! It really was amazing to see how easily, quickly and gently it works and how pleasant it is to use. I initially bought two... one for my adult daughter who has long hair, and one to keep here for when she visits so I can brush her hair. We were both so impressed that I bought several more for Christmas gifts for her friends with long hair...<br /><br />Especially when hair is wet, it is extremely important to be as gentle as possible when detangling it, or the hair will stretch, weaken, split and break... Detangling with a different comb or brush can be very painful, especially for children or anyone with conditions such as fibromyalgia. This brush is so gentle and works so quickly that it is nothing short of amazing to me.
  378. I have curly a African american hair type that tangles soo easily. I wet my hair in the shower, used this brush, and it started to detangle my hair, and soon combed right through! It's a pretty good brush.

  380. I read the glowing reviews and thought this was the brush that was going to work perfectly on my thick, wavy, midlength hair.<br /><br />It is meh...ok. The bristles are very thin and not strong. I imagine that they will break soon. It does seem to de-tangle hair quite well without ripping the hair.<br /><br />The fabric where the bristles come out of gets wet in the shower, and takes a long time to dry out - not what I would think would be a good thing for a brush claiming to be a good wet brush.<br /><br />There are a series of brushes that are all the same brush here on Amazon - I purchased several at the same time, and they are identical except for the branding.

  395. I have incredibly long hair and have always had an issue with it getting itself all wrapped up when I am sleeping. It often results in a giant clump on the back of my head, making it both difficult to reach and difficult to see. That has always made getting the tangles out quite a chore. I first noticed this product upon the 'Related Items' section on Amazon while looking at detangling sprays and figured why not. More importantly, I was intrigued as to how this product could work, it looked just like any other paddle brush. Frankly, it sounded more like a gimmick than a legitimate product. After using it for a few days, I think I know why. The bristles are a bit longer, softer, and more flexible than that of most brushes. I suspect that is the key. When each bristle hits the tangle, it moves towards where the hair itself is headed versus forcing the hair to where the bristles are. This would result in moving the tangle down and slowly causing the clump to dissipate without tying it further into a knot like a regular brush or comb might. It might seem slow at first because of it, but the knot itself isn't tightened and I think that's more important than instant headway. Due to that key fact, the tangle in the end is easier to brush out, it has less kinks in it, and overall the process is much less painful. I am very pleased with this purchase and would purchase more in a heartbeat.
  396. My kids love these brushes because they do not hurt when their hair is tangled. I originally bought one for myself but when the kids tried it, they took it from me! We ended up buying several.

  440. I should start out by telling you what kind of hair I have. I am Scottish, Irish, and Dutch. My hair is is mid back length and THICK. I don't mean normal thick.. My hairdresser will actually clear 4 hours for me. Sometimes she just has to started it and cut it because she doesn't have time to wash comb and dry. Other hair stylists will gather around the washing station to watch as the tub over flows because she can't lift all of my hair off of the drain for it empty the water. My hair also mats, not knots.. Mats like a carpet or dog hair I usually spend over an hour and a half painstakingly unraveling mats with my fingers until I could run a brush through it. Now that that's out of the way I also have a extremely sensitive scalp brushes can make me cry and I have never gotten my hair cut without my eyes watering. I got this brush as a gift from my friend who is also a hairstylist and has seen my mess on my head. This brush works my having softer more flexible bristles so when you run it through your hair, rather than pulling through the knot it is more likely to give. You just keep running it over your knot and it gently works through it just like your fingers. I am in LOVE with this brush. I will never go back to a normal brush again. No matter how matted my hair is it is impossible for me to brush my head with this thing and make it hurt. So it gently detangles my hair, no pain whatsoever and here is a big bonus! Because the bristles don't yank through the knots I have way fewer split ends and I know longer have that weird after brush shedding. I loved this brush so much a month later I went back to the store and bought my mother (who has the same hair as me) the same brush and she swears by it too. I have had it for a year now and none of the little plastic beads on the bristles have come off and no bristles have fallen or pulled off. Just be aware the bristles are very soft so if you throw it in your purse they can bend every which way. I really recommend it, it's fantastic!

  507. Go back 32 years with me. I'm a cute chubby little 4 year old getting my morning hair style for another tough day of kindergarten. (Yes we start early up in the mountains.) My Mom, bless her heart was on her last baby and boy were they saving the best for last! She'd take the time to braid my hair, put ribbons and bows in the long deep dark brown hair. She'd sing The Little Indian song to me because I wanted to look just like my Dad's sisters. She'd send me off to school and I'd come home every single day with no hair doo to speak of unless you are Mr. Yahoo Serious. Knots, clumps, dirt, a worm from time to time, once a dog treat...all have been found in my hair over the years. Finally, giving into the fact I would never be prim for more than an hour a day she gave me a Dorthy Hamill and I was Sarah The Fat Boy for years.<br /><br />Fast forward those horrible years called life before 25 and we're to about 11 years ago. I had hair down to the middle of my back that was so thick hair stylists couldn't believe their brushes. Never processed, and hardly every dry as it was that thick and long. Still hard as heck to comb, but long hair was just something I needed. No pain, no gain! Then life kicked in, we'll fast forward past some surgery, some weight loss, a dash of stress and one giant incurable disease that called for medication that took all that hair away. I started over.<br /><br />We are now in the near past (last week), I'm a okay. My hair on the other hand has gone through several lengths and came full circle to hair nearly to my waist. This hair is thin, and without serious amounts of hydrotherapie or maybe lard would not comb / brush / iron / pull / etc thorough tangles. Often I would just braid a tangle into the the fold as cutting or leaving was the only option that day. I was losing more hair than a very large old stuffed cat, should I try to brush my hair. Then I stumbled upon The Wet Brush.<br /><br />Now, I've tried every comb, clicker brush, no nibby metal prong, wooden, plastic, silicone, pick, finger comb, brush combo out there. Thousands of dollars over the years looking for something to brush out my uber thick non curly hair and then my uber thin still tangledy hair. I have a closet of conditioners that makes most supply warehouses look weak. I figured, what's one more brush for less than $10 with all these stars?! I ordered it. Prime always makes it easier for me!<br /><br />*triangle & harp music* *fade to color ala Wizard of OZ*<br /><br />I didn't wash my hair for a long time as I was going to put a rinse in it. I asked my Mom to brush my hair out over a towel because it makes such a mess. Besides who better than the woman who started the long hair love affair of mine only to rip it away with a sassy skater cut?!<br />I digress, to the night in question. She starts to brush and I hand her the ultra de-tangler just in case! She's not exactly a sweet fawn with my hair or my mouth. Weird part? It doesn't hurt and I'm thinking, my gosh my hair must be really really, grody greasy... ewewewewwwwww. Then she flips the first portion over my shoulder and I said what on earth are you doing?! If you're not going to bother to brush it, I'll make someone else do it. She replies...Sarah...there is no hair coming out and I did brush it! It's totally smooth, look! Sit still and shut up! She keeps brushing and it's like nothing is going on back there. Certainly not a replay from 32 years ago with her brushing my feral child hair and me yelling b*stard out my cute 4 year old mouth. When she was done there was a small bunch of hair...a normal amount of shedding. My scalp was not bleeding. I was not crying, nor was she. The towel was not playing a game of Harry and The Almost Henderson's. My hair was smooth, brushed out, ready for a rinse.<br /><br />Then this morning I washed my hair very quickly for an appointment and used the brush and same result. No issues. I don't know that this is the Shroud of Turin or even the secret to Martha Stewart looking not a day over 60...but this brush is something! Order one. See the difference. Feel it. I'm a realist, aka pessimist. This brush is cooler than the other side of my pillow and I will never go without one again. Then come back and tell me how to get away with yelling cuss words to get my Mom's goose with no tangles?at this is the Shroud of Turin or even the secret to Martha Stewart looking not a day over 60...but this brush is something! I was skeptical about this, but with no detangler, I was able to get through all of that wet hair in about three minutes. So much easier than combing!   792. My daughter has been begging me to get the &#34;As Seen on TV&#34; detangling brush. So my first instinct is to go to my Amazon app and see how much they have it for and read some reviews. This came across my search and from reading other reviews it made me think this might work instead. Hmmmmmmm...... When my daughter opened the box she looked at me and asked why I got her a brush. LOL! It was my fault I didn't look closer while I was researching this product, I didn't realize this is just a regular brush like other brushes in our house. We did however put it thru some testing.<br /><br />Background:<br />I have 2 daughters 10 & 8 yrs. old. My 10 yrs. old have Type 3C - Curly Coily hair, my 8 yrs. old have 3A-3B - Curly Spiraly hair and myself have straight hair; all pass shoulder length (Yes, my hubby is one lucky guy! He gets to unclog the tub once a week. LOL).<br /><br />Product testing:<br />The Wet Brush Vs. $1 Dollar Tree Paddle Brush<br />The Wet Brush Vs. $4 Detangling Brush from Walmart (Goody Brand)<br />To my hair no difference from my $1 Dollar Tree and Goody brush. To my 8 yrs. old Curly spiral daughter no difference. Still the same &#34;ouch!&#34; scream and whine. To my 10 yrs. old Curly coiled hair at first I didn't hear complaints, which is good. But it took me a minute to realize the brush bristles are bendable thin like so the effect was nearly a trick. The brush only brushes the top part of her hair and the bottom close to her scalp wasn't being touched at all that is why no scream. In this case I had to take a comb to part the hair to half and by doing that it was time consuming and yes - can you imagine trying to part the 'rat nest' like in half? My daughter started whining and there goes the &#34;ouch!&#34;. Needles to say compare to my $1 Dollar Tree brush and good ol' Goody brush it's still the same result. With Dollar Tree and Goody I only had to part my kids hair 4 ways, with this brush about 6 ways. 3 Stars since it's not a bad brush but not a GREAT brush!

The reason that the smell is so distinct is because the brush is in such high demand that it comes in from our factory and gets shipped directly out. This does not allow the proper ventilation time for the smell to dissipate.Some brushes that I have in the warehouse do have a little odor.....It is not bad for your health. The smell usually dissipates within one to two weeks. I have found that by using baking soda on the brush, it also helps take the odor away.&#34;<br /><br />They do work really well, so I have put up with having to &#34;age&#34; them in order to be able to use them.

  888. We love this brush. Very simple brush. It is one solid piece from handle to top. It is rubberized all throughout but very rigid. It feels good in your hand without slipping.<br /><br />The needles are ball tipped and each tip is smooth which is very gentle to the scalp. At the root of the needles is a rubbery cushion which absorbs the impact if you accidentally push it to your scalp.<br /><br />It is called a wet brush because it is designed for both wet and dry hair. My daughter always complain when my wife brushes her hair after shower. My 5-yr-old has a long and very fine hair, this brush made it much easier.<br /><br />One negative thing is that you really can not choose the color.   893. Writing reviews is a chore and I rarely do it for anything. But this is one of those few products in life that is THAT good. I've seen stylists and their assistants get visibly frustrated trying to comb through my hair after washing it at a salon. It normally takes me 5 solid minutes of raking through, starting responsibly from the bottom and working up. Seriously, this brush whips through that same hair, top to bottom, with one fell swoop. I love it, I no longer dread the after-shower routine, and am planning to give a bunch of these brushes as stocking stuffers for my daughters and pals. It's that good.   895. I own a collection of hair brushes ranging from the drug store/super market variety to the fancier Mason Pearson Detangler and baby brushes. I have 2 daughters currently aged 9 and 7. Both of them and I have long hair. My older daughter has hair that is so thick that her braid looks like a rope. My younger daughter's hair is so fine that it tangles in the wind into a rat nest. After showers we used to use Suave detangler or something similar and spend a good 15 or 20 min brushing and separating all the knots per kid - even after conditioner and detangler. Now that we use the \\"Wet Brush\\" I haven't reached for the detangler once. The brush doesn't hurt and does detangle. It makes hair look shiny if you brush it while dry, and it easily goes through wet hair. At most, it takes 2 minutes to brush their hair (even with bed head). Sometimes i hold their hair in a pony tail and brush below my hand so it doesn't pull which works fine - it's pretty amazing. I bought 2 back up brushes because we loved it so much. I highly recommend it.

There's a lot less breakage than with a firmer one and I have to be trying to make it pull on my scalp. I'd imagine this would be great for parents for that reason. This is great for curly hair since it breaks less, pulls less, and works on wet hair (the only time you can brush curly hair). I highly recommend this brush. It detangles really well and doesn't hurt at all. Even though the bristles are soft and bendable, none have become bent or broken. The only thing is that I wish you could pick the colors, but that's pretty minor.

I usually start with the underside first and work my way around my head. I have thick, long hair and it is much nicer to use than a traditional brush but a wide tooth comb works great too.

The greasy feeling of innumerable hair products on hand just to manage a braid that requires repeating again at night. So far it's been my favorite part if of parenting. I didn't do a lot of research but I'm fairly certain it will run out of magical power eventually. How do I replenish it's mana?   1066. Honestly I didn't believe all the hype about this brush until I saw my sister use one. Since we were young, my grandma would get us a soft bristle hair brush every year for Christmas. We both have extremely thick hair. My sister's is super long and silky, and I'm very tender headed (with coarse, curly hair) so these were always the best option to avoid tears :). I've used detangling spray all my life and it never seems to work like it should, especially after a day out on the lake or in the ocean. I saw her use her Wet Brush after spending all day on the boat skiing and swimming and riding around in the wind and it brushed through it with ease. She didn't even flinch. So, of course, I had to get one.<br /><br />I LOVE IT. I was kind of skeptical since, when I opened the box, it had &#34;hard bristles&#34;, but it goes through my hair with absolutely no pull at all. I've had it for a month and haven't had to clean it out yet, whereas I would have to clean my old one out every other day...at least. (Thick haired girls feel my pain). Overall I love this brush. It's been a lifesaver for my hair.

  1068. Works well for hair of average thickness, but if you have REALLY thick, curly hair like I do, it's just &#34;okay&#34;. The bristles are more flexible than those of a regular brush, and I suppose that's how it detangles without all the pulling, but for me, they don't go far enough into my hair. The outer layers get brushed adequately, but the inner layers remain tangly and unbrushed. My hair is waist-length and curly as a telephone handset cord, so you can imagine the ordeal of brushing it, even a section at a time. I usually end up using my regular brush in addition to this one, but it does help get some of the tangles out. Every little bit helps. :-)
  1069. My oldest daughter has long, fine hair that gets easily tangled. Her hairdresser recommended The Wet Brush to me. I ordered it on Amazon--a full size that came with a smaller travel size as well. The handles on these two feel rubbery, and the brush really does work wonders. It glides through the hair with ease with or without the use of conditioner, detangler, etc, resulting in tangle free hair. I use it on my daughter's hair as well as mine, in fact.<br /><br />Now, the bad. I liked the brush I got so much that I saw The Wet Brush also at Bed, Bath, and Beyond one day and decided to buy another one to keep just for me in my bathroom so I could stop using the one I bought for my daughter. This one has a plastic, hard handle. It does not work nearly as well as the others I purchased from Amazon with the rubbery handles. The bristles don't look different, so I'm not sure what the difference is other than the handles (which I wouldn't think would account for the performance), but this second brush does not move smoothly through the hair at all. It doesn't glide. It gets caught and pulls at the hair, resulting in ouchies and seems to even contribute to more tangling.<br /><br />I don't know if I would purchase again because there seems to be some sort of quality control issue. I love the first brush (and its mini size companion), but the second one is terrible, hence the 3 star rating.

  1109. It's the best tool for detangling that I used on my kid. It works somewhat while wet, but I don't think it's a good idea. It's always easier to brush when dry or drying. The \\"spikes\\" are very fine so I don't think it will last as long as the usual ones. But that's the price I'm willing to pay. Also, the brush handle is coated with some nice to touch plastic. From experience this softer layer doesn't last as much as simple hard plastic. So it get 4 stars.<br /><br />For hard cases of tangling you should be looking for conditioner. Some very cheap ones will do well if you don't care too much about the look of kids - the perfect silky voluminous look. For that look it gets expensive for adults. For natural alternatives the best so far is whole milk, and egg is better. A little bit of oil help but it doesn't look good. Since egg yolk smells, the best is egg white. Forget about what people tell you about the benefits. The slippery sticky stuff just can detangle hair if you use it as a conditioner. Egg white powder is much easier to handler and cheaper since you don't need to use a whole egg every time.<br /><br />Of course these natural and potential cheaper alternatives are not as good as some chemicals, the chief ingredients of which is soluble in water and oil at the SAME time. Therefore I need help from brush like this.<br /><br />I brought two \\"assorted color\\" brush, fully aware that there is no choice. But I ended up with two black brush. The way Amazon deal with multiple sellers is that when I order, I only see 4 non-black colors. Now when I writing the review I see a different picture with the 5th black color. To add insult to injury, the individually package have the words written on it \\"assorted color for the family\\".<br /><br />The seller is Discount Infomercial Products. I can't even seem to be able to leave a feedback. It should go back to eBay, or Aliexpress.

The wet brush enables me to brush my daughter's hair without tears while she brushes her teeth. Brushing hair is almost a non- issue now! ( for both of us). Do not press down on your scalp as the tips of the brush are pretty sharp/small to allow it to glide through the hair. I dab on a little conditioner on dry hair and start at the ends. Hold the brush loosely so that you can make gentle corrections to the brush when you encounter a tangle.

One of my daughter's classmates mentioned the Wet Brush to her, and she talked about it daily until I finally bought it for her. We were both excited to use it, but disappointed to find that it's truly no better for her hair than the Knot Genie or any of the other detanglers we've tried. The bristles are very soft and flexible, but they don't truly detangle - they just glide over top of the mats in her hair. They don't reach all the way through to the underneath of her hair - it's like the bristles only glide over the very top layer. I still have to comb through not only the very tangly under layer of her hair, but also tackle each individual tangle in the top layer with this brush, which still pulls and makes her spazz out, no matter how gentle I am.<br /><br />It's definitely not any better than all the other brushes just like it out there. It would probably work better for someone with thinner hair who isn't so prone to matting.

  1293. For anyone like me who is wondering &#34;how on Earth does this brush that looks like something from the Dollar Store intend to flow through my wet hair without ripping off my scalp? And for a price that doesn't make me sad?&#34; here's what I can tell you:<br /><br />Yes, it actually does what it says it will do. Sadly though, no, it isn't magic. It's actually kind of clever. The &#34;bristles&#34; of the brush are VERY thin and VERY flexible. And the &#34;base&#34; where the bristles meet the brush is a bit squishy as well, presumably so the bristles don't snap right off when they bend. So anyway, rather than getting caught in your hair and tugging/tearing at it, the bristles simply bend out of the way. So it isn't as if you'll get it through your wet hair on the first try exactly. It's more like you'll work out the kinks until you actually can run the brush completely through your wet hair in one sweep.<br /><br />My own hair is LONG. It is thick, it likes to tangle, and generally be a hassle. This thing isn't my everyday brush, but when I need to smooth out my wet hair in a hurry, it's a life saver.

Though it detangled, I kept hearing that dreaded snapping sound of breakage. It's like they weren't even there. I would feel a little bit of resistance and then it would melt away.   1471. I've been using this brush for about a month now. I get what people like about it, and I do like it, but it isn't exactly &#34;detangling&#34; the hair all that much. It's more like it organizes the hair into smaller rows, but the tangles are still in the rows. I use it on my wet hair (which is naturally straight but is tangly right out of the shower), but then I have to use a real brush to get all the tangles out for blow drying. It's because the bristles are so soft and bendy, they just go around the tangle. Which is nice in that it doesn't hurt or pull your hair, but it doesn't actually get the knot out. Hope this is making sense! I recommend it though, for a first round on wet hair.

  1474. I got this at the local Bed Bath & Beyond after reading reviews here. I have fine fragile thick 4a/b African American hair & these brushes...I have the paddle version ,too... are fantastic for my hair ! The bristles have just enough give to get thru my hair without ripping it out. At first I tried the highly recommended Denman brush ,but those things act like shredders & weed whackers on my hair...they rip it out something awful. May as well use a lawnmower with dull blades ! With these brushes I'm able to detangle & brush my wet hair & distribute oils for hot oil treatments, regular & deep conditioners & other hair products without causing a epic broken hair catastrophe. Between these brushes, my Tangle Teezer, & my huge Hercules Sagemann rake combs, my hair is in great condition with far fewer split ends & breakage. You're crazy if you don't get one of these !!

  1587. The Wet Brush does exactly what it is advertised to do. My hair is long & thick and it was an ordeal to brush it after washing until I bought the Wet Brush. Now the brush slides through my hair sooooooooo easily it is almost unbelievable. I bought the Wet Brush & the Sharkk brush (thinking they were the same) since they were part of Amazon's \\"Add On\\" (the Wet Brush was $8.96 and the Sharkk was $3.96.) Well, they are not the same. The Wet Brush is excellent in everyway but the Sharkk Brush is flimsy and works okay with dry hair but not with wet hair (brushing conditioner through wet hair.)   1588. We have 2 daughters with long, thick hair and it's been a nightmare trying to brush their hair. It's been especially rough with our 2 year old who has mid-back length hair and would cry and fight just at the sight of the brush or comb. It's a totally different story with the Wet Brush. I first used it right after our toddler's bath and she was apprehensive at first, (as was I) thinking it was the regular brush, but when I got started and she realized it wasn't pulling her hair, she calmed down and we haven't had a problem since. The bristles are really skinny and flexible, so they drag through the hair rather than just pulling it. It does take a little longer to work out big tangles, but it's worth it for how smoothly it works. We've used it on wet and dry hair and have great results both ways. The brush leaves their hair much smoother and softer than with a regular brush, and doesn't pull out even an eighth of the hair the girls were having yanked out before. We're definitely stocking up on a few more of these!

  1597. This brush is the best thing to happen to my head in months. After an over-bleaching accident last year, every morning has been a painful battle to brush my just-out-of-the-shower-bleach-damaged wet hair enough to get it into a french braid. I've tried wide tooth combs, detangler, conditioner, and my regular brush and everything HURT! This brush has put a stop to the daily torture.<br />That being said, it is not a miracle brush. The reason it gets through knots so well is because of its very thin and well spaced bristles. However, because they are so thin, they bend with contact to something solid like the back of your neck. So, with wet hair, the brush will completely detangle the sides and get a lot of the back, but not everything. I've found that a first run through with the brush gets out the worst tangles, and a wide tooth comb gets out the rest. With dry hair, there's no need for a second run through. And all without pain!
